importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Diwali is celebrated on this date, marking the autumn festival of lights observed by over a billion South Asians worldwide.
Sikhs commemorate Bandi Chhor Divas on this date, marking the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 Hindu kings from imprisonment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The festival occurs annually during autumn, typically between October and November, with Diwali falling on October 20 in 2025.

keyTakeAways: Diwali is a major cultural and religious festival celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists globally.

The festival symbolizes the triumph of light over darkness, good over evil, and is rooted in various myths including the return of Rama and Sita, Lord Krishna's victory over Narakasura, and the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings.

Diwali lasts five days, with key observances including Dhanteras (purchase of gold/silver), Choti Diwali (defeat of Narakasura), Lakshmi Puja (worship of goddess of wealth), Padwa (husband-wife bond), and Bhai Dooj (sibling bond).
Despite its religious origins, Diwali has become a widely celebrated cultural festival that transcends faith and is observed by people of many backgrounds.

In some regions, Diwali marks the beginning of the new financial year, with businesses opening new accounts and gambling games like teen patti being considered auspicious due to a legend involving Shiva and Parvati.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diwali, the festival of lights, is celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists worldwide on October 20, 2025. Rooted in myths of triumph over darkness—such as Rama’s return from exile, Krishna’s defeat of Narakasura, and the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings—the festival symbolizes light over darkness, good over evil, and spiritual and social renewal. It lasts five days, each with unique traditions including Dhanteras (purchasing gold and cleaning homes), Choti Diwali (defeat of Narakasura), Lakshmi Puja (worship of prosperity), Padwa (husband-wife bond), and Bhai Dooj (sibling love). While deeply religious, Diwali has evolved into a cultural celebration embraced by people across faiths and regions. Celebrated in India, Nepal, Malaysia, Fiji, and the U.S., Diwali marks not only spiritual reflection but also economic renewal, family unity, and community bonding.
title: It’s Diwali, a time for light, community and fresh starts
